docs.lead_paragraph: In a tactical retreat, the Bush administration told Congress today that it would accept equal prescription drug benefits for people in the traditional Medicare program and those who join private health plans. Administration officials had long insisted on more generous drug benefits for enrollees in private plans, especially the preferred provider organizations that steer patients to certain doctors and hospitals. Officials said they were bowing to political reality and giving up, at least for now, on a two-tier benefit.

headline.main: BUSH WILL ACCEPT IDENTICAL BENEFITS ON MEDICARE DRUGS

docs.abstract: Bush administration tells Congress it would accept equal prescription drug benefits for people in traditional Medicare program and those who join private health plans; administration officials say they are bowing to political reality and giving up, at least for now, two-tier benefit in which more generous drug benefits would be reserved for enrollees in private plans, especially preferred provider organizations that steer patients to certain doctors and hospitals; move amounts to offer to compromise with Senate plan to give same Medicare drug benefits to everybody; Congressional Budget Office tells senators that fewer than 10 percent of 40 million Medicare beneficiaries would join preferred provider plans if prescription drug benefits are same as for those enrolled in traditional fee-for-service Medicare plans; Senate Finance Committee will vote June 12 on bill that offers identical drug benefits to Medicare beneficiaries and those in private health plans; Pres Bush and Republican-controlled Congress have agreed to spend $400 billion on drug benefits and other changes in Medicare over next 10 years (M)
docs.snippet: In a tactical retreat, the Bush administration told Congress today that it would accept equal prescription drug benefits for people in the traditional Medicare program and those who join private health plans.    Administration officials had long...

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress begins a politically polarizing debate over prescription drug benefits for the elderly this week, a central issue is whether private health plans can deliver better care, at lower cost, than the traditional Medicare program created 38 years ago. Much of the debate will focus on the merits of private plans: Will they be acceptable to Medicare beneficiaries? Will they work? Will they save money? Will they improve the quality of care?

headline.main: MEDICARE DEBATE FOCUSES ON MERITS OF PRIVATE PLANS

docs.abstract: Central issue in debate over prescription drug benefits for elderly is whether private health plans can deliver better care, at lower cost, than traditional Medicare program created 38 years ago; Congress could easily add drug benefits to Medicare, but there is much more fundamental debate going on about future of Medicare and role of government; issue defines philosophical differences between Republicans and Democrats; Pres Bush, most Republicans in Congress and some Democrats are determined that Medicare must not pay for prescription drugs as it pays doctors, hospitals and other health care providers, with rigid, complex statutory formula that often bears little relation to realities of local health care markets; former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, testifying last week before Senate committee, calls Medicare obsolete and antiquated; liberal Democrats say Republicans are trying to privatize program, although some Democrats, including Sen Edward M Kennedy, indicate they will work with Republicans to pass legislation, even while fighting over details; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Reverse Robin Hood,'' by Bob Herbert (column, June 2):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''The Reverse Robin Hood,'' by Bob Herbert (column, June 2):

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate committees will take up two bills this week that could help many Americans cope with the ever-rising cost of prescription drugs. With both parties looking toward the 2004 elections, the chances are improving for useful drug legislation to be approved by Congress and signed into law by President Bush. The most important bill, to be considered by the Senate Finance Committee, would add a prescription drug benefit to the Medicare program for elderly and disabled Americans. This is a badly needed benefit that would drag Medicare into the modern age by including drug coverage alongside the traditional hospital and medical coverage.
docs.abstract: Editorial backs two bills being considered by Senate that promise some relief from high costs of prescription drugs; one would add drug benefit to Medicare and offer elderly choice of using traditional Medicare or new private plans; other would speed lower-cost generic drugs to market when brand-name drugs' patents run out

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has worked hard over the last two years to project an image as a low-key, constituent-minded junior senator from New York. But in one weekend, she has abandoned that mantle and, for the first time, embraced her status as a celebrity senator. The release of her memoir, ''Living History,'' on Monday, meant Mrs. Clinton spent the weekend drawing the kind of publicity that she has not had since being sworn in two years ago as the only first lady to take a seat in Congress.

headline.main: Political Memo; Book Gives Mrs. Clinton New Turn in the Spotlight

docs.abstract: Political Memo on latest spotlight shining on Sen Hillary Clinton as she publicizes memoir Living History; photo; her circumscribed discussion of her marriage and Monica Lewinsky affair quoted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE burger-slinging days were supposed be finished. I had a job, tax problems and a midtown studio crammed with unwanted stuff. Then one day, far below sales quota, I recalled my writing ambition. Thus began a leap from a résumé full of executive jobs, each loathed by me and respected by someone other than me, to ''I will be your waiter tonight, sir'' at the Paradise Cafe in Sag Harbor. It's a village of quiet dignity and a rich literary history, and the Paradise is plugged into it. There's an excellent bookstore up front, and my writer pal runs it. Another writing peer introduced me to the owner-chef, who has a literary interest and hired me despite my not having feigned a grin for tips in years.
docs.abstract: Mitchell McMahon essay on trading corporate executive life for that of waiter, college student and would-be writer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MARIA TORRES works in a convenience store in East Hartford. She does not have insurance, and last month she felt pains in her chest. She waited for three weeks, then went to the emergency room at Hartford Hospital. Once there, Ms. Torres said, a worker at a desk asked her if she had insurance. She didn't. ''I can't afford a doctor,'' Ms. Torres said. ''And they didn't tell me about free care. My sister told me about it. It's the first time I've ever heard of these things.''

headline.main: At Hospitals, A Cushion For the Poor

docs.abstract: Article on decade-old dispute over what Connecticut Attorney Gen Richard Blumenthal calls misuse of free-bed funds by 21 hospitals, including Yale New Yaven Hospital; Blumenthal, saying hospitals need to do better job telling patients about availability of free beds, has sued Yale-New Haven Hospital over its use of fund; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A newly opened dental spa on White Plains Road is offering patients relaxation aromatherapy, heated massage dental chairs, lemon-scented hot face towels, hand wraps and warm neck wraps in addition to the usual fare of dental treatments. At the Scarsdale Dental Spa, patients also can listen to meditative music on headphones or watch movies on DVD or DirecTV; plasma screens are mounted over each dental chair. New to the northeast United States, such spas are already a trend in some European countries and in California, Texas and Florida, said Rick Gabrielly, chief operating officer of the spa.

headline.main: Would You Prefer Novocaine Or Massage With That Filling?

docs.lead_paragraph: What is it with this economy, anyway? Going strictly by the numbers, the most recent recession has been mild in comparison to previous downturns. Since the economy peaked in March 2001, the major markers of economic health -- industrial output, personal income and wholesale and retail sales -- have all traced smaller declines than in the average post-World War II recession. That's why many economists, among them Jeffrey Frankel, a professor at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, are inclined to dismiss today's complaints about economic stress and anxiety. ''People got spoiled by the 90's boom,'' Frankel says. ''They forgot what recessions are like.'' But Frankel concedes there's something odd about this latest economic decline. After a short-lived retreat in 2001, gross domestic product after adjustment for inflation actually grew throughout 2002 and managed a 1.9 percent gain in the first quarter of 2003. Yet the economy shed more than 500,000 jobs between January and April. And as Frankel notes dryly, ''Wages are not doing so well, either.'' The latest evidence of wage stagnation: the Labor Department's report last month that the average weekly paycheck, once inflation and seasonal factors are considered, shrank 0.3 percent from March to April of this year. All the contradictory signals have economists wondering what manner of beast stands before them. ''In recent economic history,'' says Robert Hall, an economist at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, ''there's been nothing quite like this continued modest G.D.P. growth combined with continuing declines in employment.''
docs.abstract: Harris Collingwood article on unusual characteristics of current recession; says numbers indicate it is mild when compared to previous downturns, with major markers of economic health showing only small declines; notes growth of gross domestic product is counterintuitive to recession and, coupled with loss of jobs and wage stagnation, latest decline presents conundrum; says dichotomies between those making huge amounts of money and others reduced to counting pennies only add to puzzle; wonders if Americans intuitively feel that best days have come and gone; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is no secret that those who support abortion restrictions believe this is their time. Republican control of Congress and the White House gives them an opening to enact new limits on abortion. And by the time the inevitable legal challenges to these laws reach the Supreme Court, they believe, new, more sympathetic faces will be on the bench. Last week, the House passed a ban on the procedure that abortion opponents call partial-birth abortion; the Senate had passed the legislation in March. Congress is also considering the Unborn Victims of Violence Act, which would allow prosecutors to charge someone who kills or injures a pregnant woman in the commission of a federal crime with harming the fetus. In the House, sponsors raced to rename it ''Laci and Connor's Law'' for the California murder case of the pregnant Laci Peterson. It could be considered in the Senate this summer.

headline.main: June 1-7; Good Times For Abortion Foes
